utterance: Hello, Mr. Batsby.
Hello.
My name's Dr. Vanita Gavies.
Right.
And I'm one of the psychiatrists  who works here.
Right, OK.
OK, can you tell me what's brought you here today?
Yeah, well,  I was referred to you by my GP.
Right.
And he referred me to you because, erm, well,  my wife thinks I'm drinking too much.
Right, I see.
And do you think you're drinking too  much?
Er, well, I... Yeah, I... Looking at it from her point of view, I suppose I do  like a drink, yeah.
Right.
Maybe we can just explore that a little bit more.
Yeah.
How
much would you say you drank in a day?
Now?
Yeah.
Oh, it's crept up over the years.
Erm...
Well, I suppose if I'm... If I'm honest, er, yeah, I drink about a bottle of vodka a day.
Yeah.
And how long have you been drinking that much for?
Well, as I say, it's crept  up, erm, er, a few years now.
A few years.
Can you make it a bit more specific?
Two years,  three years, five years?
Well, I mean, as I say, it's crept up.
I mean, initially I  just used to have a couple of drinks after work.
Right.
Cos I got a pretty responsible  job and, erm, I just found a drink calmed me down, you know.
And, erm, then I got more  responsibility and I found a bit more alcohol helped me, so, yeah.
Yes, I'm drinking about  a bottle a day now.
OK.
So you'd say you've had about the last two years, three years?
Yeah, about that.
About that, OK.
And do you drink anything else apart from vodka?
Yeah,  erm, after work I normally go to the pub and, er, I have two to four pints of bitter or  lager.
Right, OK.
And would that be every day?
Yeah.
Well, especially, you know, Monday  to Friday when I'm working.
But at weekends I normally go down the local pub and I have  a few at lunchtime.
Right.
And how much is a few?
OK, only about two to four pints.
Right,
OK.
And then, so, on a weekday, you take about, you have about two to four pints after work  and then you come home and drink about a bottle of vodka?
Yeah, well, no, well, I don't come  home and drink a bottle of vodka.
I drink, erm, I drink during the day.
So would you
drink throughout... Not when I'm working, mind you.
Not when you're working?
Apart from  lunchtime.
OK.
Not when I'm at work.
So when do you start drinking during the day?
Erm...
On an average day?
Well, after I'm up and dressed and have me breakfast at home.
Right,
so after breakfast.
And again, when did that start?
A couple of years ago.
A couple of
years ago, OK.
And what about the weekend?
Is it the same at the weekend?
Mm.
And would  you drink, you go to the pub at lunchtime at the weekend, would you drink more than  a bottle of vodka during the day at the weekend?
Er, no.
It would be about the same, would
it?
Yeah.
OK.
And are there ever regular times when you drink more than what you've told  me?
No.
There aren't?
OK.
And is it just beer and vodka, would you drink wine?
No, I don't.
We used to drink wine, my wife used to, when we had an evening meal together, sometimes  we had a bottle of red or a bottle of white together, half a bottle.
But since she started  complaining that she thought I was, you know, really shoving it down my throat, er, she  sort of nailed that on the head, so we don't do that any more.
And would you say you have  to drink more to get the same effect from the alcohol?
Yeah, the same calming effect,  yeah.
Same calming effect?
Yeah.
Do you ever have days where you don't drink, or periods  where you don't drink?
Mm-hm.
When was the last time you had that?
Er, a few months ago  now, when she really had had a go at me and I thought to myself, well, maybe I'll give  it a try again.
It wasn't the first time, but erm... And how long did that last for?
How long did that last for?
Oh, about three days.
Three days.
And in that time, did you  experience any, any physical feelings at all?
Yes, I did.
I mean, I was shaking, I  got very shaky, I got... I was on edge all the time, I, I was not working properly and  I was sweating.
Right.
And I just felt absolutely lousy.
So you had to take time off work?
No,  I didn't take time, I couldn't, I didn't dare take time off work.
I just said I had  a bit of a cold.
Right.
Erm, but erm, I thought to myself, well, I can't carry on like this.
And so I had a couple of large vodkas.
Right.
And that, that made you feel better?
And that  got me back on the straight and narrow.
Did you ever feel, do you ever get those similar  sorts of feelings in the morning when you wake up?
Yeah.
You do?
Nowadays, yeah.
And
what, what happens when you have the drink in the morning that makes you feel better?
Yes, it does.
Right.
Yeah.
If you don't have that drink in the morning, what happens?
Well,
by the time I get to work, I just feel, again, I feel pretty shaky and very on edge.
Right.
And as I say, I don't touch it when I'm at work because I've got a pretty responsible  job.
And I don't, as I say, I don't touch it at work.
And you work as a bank manager?
I do, yeah.
OK.
Has anyone, has anyone commented apart from your wife about your drinking?
Have you ever had any more serious health problems from your drinking?
Have you ever  seen the doctor or had, sometimes people get loss of memory or fits, very serious shakes,  they need to go into hospital.
Have you ever had anything like that?
No, no, no, no, no,  no, no, I've touched it with nothing like that.
OK.
And have you ever seen, you went  to your GP?
Yeah.
Did you do any physical health tests at all?
He does some blood tests.
And did that show anything at all?
He said the liver wasn't too good.
Right.
And then  because of my, you know, my wife threatened to leave me basically.
That's what got me  to see the GP.
And he did some blood tests and he said, your liver's, you know, and he  told me I've got to cut it down a bit.
What did he say about?
And then he said he was  going to refer me to somebody to talk about it.
Right.
OK.
And how did you feel about  that?
Well, I wasn't exactly over the moon when he suggested it.
But, well, I suppose,  you know, if it's a choice of coming to see you and then or my wife leaving me, I came  to see you.
I don't want to lose you.
So I can see that it's had quite an impact at home.
Yeah.
What about outside the home?
How's your drinking affected jobs or anything else?
It
hasn't affected my job.
What about relationships other than your wife with family, friends?
Well, any other serious consequences?
I suppose, yeah, I have to go to family dues and dragged  along there.
But I mean, I don't.
I mean, I avoid mixing with my work colleagues socially.
I find that bores me because, you know, if I'm in the pub with them, I've tried it once  and I found I needed a drink.
And, you know, I thought, well, I'm going to put me foot  in it if I carry on like this.
And I left early and I just make excuses.
I don't socialise  with them anymore.
All right.
OK.
Thanks for coming to talk to me today.
Thank you.
